newsitem.title: GERMANY: Bonn bans CD calling for racist killings.
newsitem.headline: Bonn bans CD calling for racist killings.

text.p: German authorities have blacklisted a recording of neo-Nazi songs urging Germans to kill foreigners, a spokeswoman for the Family Ministry said on Wednesday.
She said Family Minister Claudia Nolte had put the CD entitled "12 German Sing-Along Songs" on an index of banned publications considered dangerous to young people.
"The recording has potential to incite racial hatred," Nolte said in an internal communique to the BPJS federal office assigned to protect juveniles from dangerous publications.
She recommended that the BPJS should pass the recording of songs by a pop band called The Turk Hunters from Zillertal to prosecutors to launch a criminal investigation.
"The potential for violence has reached a new dimension. We are seeing how neo-Nazi propaganda is becoming increasingly vicious and sensational," Nolte said in a statement.

"Extreme right-wing groups have now started encouraging racial hatred on their CDs...and even calling for killings (of foreigners). The Turk Hunters from Zillertal is a particularly aggressive example."

The government has been clamping down on neo-Nazi propaganda and activities, securing several high-profile convictions including that of U.S. neo-Nazi Gary Lauck who was jailed for four years in 1996 for inciting racial hatred in Germany.
But the authorities are becoming particularly concerned about an increase in the use of rock music recordings and concerts to convey a neo-Nazi message of racial hatred.
One song on the CD includes the lines: "On the North Sea coast, on the Aryan beach, we don't want any kaffers in our country."
A song called Kreuzberg Nights, referring to an area in Berlin with a large Turkish community, has the line: "They lie there in their blood, I must say the sight of this does me good."
The mass-circulation Bild newspaper reported this week that the authorities had blacklisted about 130 recordings including CDs, cassettes and records by extreme right-wing groups since 1991.
The ban means the recordings cannot be advertised or sold or made available to under-18s.
